title: How to Cook a Cantaloupe

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 375–400 °F (191–204 °C).
steps.description: Turn the oven on to the “bake” setting. If your cantaloupe is still a lighter yellow and doesn’t have a smell, the melon is unripe and a higher temperature is ideal for cooking it. If your cantaloupe smells sweet, this means that it’s ripe, so lower the temperature to 375 °F (191 °C) and cook for the same amount of time to prevent the melon from becoming too shriveled in the oven. You can begin preparing the cantaloupe as the oven heats to the right temperature.

steps.headline: Wash the cantaloupe in cool water and cut it in half.
steps.description: Rinse the outside of the cantaloupe and rub the skin with your fingers to remove any waxy coating or other dirt that might be on it. Then, take a sharp knife and cut it through the center to expose the seeds. It doesn’t matter which direction you cut through the melon, as long as you go through the center to make 2 halves.

steps.headline: Scoop the seeds out with a large spoon and set them aside to roast them.
steps.description: Place the spoon at the top of the opening where the seeds are attached to the flesh of the melon. Use the spoon and your hands to pull the seeds and the “netting” out of the center cavity. The netting is made up of tough fibers that hold the seeds in place. If you’re planning to also roast the seeds, place them in a bowl and put them in the refrigerator while you prepare the rest of the cantaloupe. If you aren’t planning to roast the seeds, you can discard them now.

steps.headline: Slice the cantaloupe into bite-sized pieces for roasting.
steps.description: Cut the cantaloupe halves into wedges by slicing through the middle, and then cut each wedge into chunks in whichever size and shape you prefer. Keep in mind that the pieces will shrivel up slightly as they caramelize in the oven, so don’t make them too small! It’s best to keep them at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) wide. It’s safe to keep the skin on the cantaloupe while you roast it, so don’t worry about removing it.Tip: If you want the melon to have a more aesthetically pleasing appearance, try using a melon baller to make pieces that are all the same shape and size.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the cubes with 2 tbsp (8 g) of sugar if you like your cantaloupe sweet.
steps.description: If your cantaloupe is unripe, it will likely be watery and not very sweet. Toss the cubes in sugar or give them a light dusting so that most of them are covered. This will help them caramelize in the oven. If the cantaloupe is already ripe and sweet, you can skip this step since the natural sugars in the melon will be enough to make the pieces caramelize.

steps.headline: Arrange the cantaloupe on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper.
steps.description: Put a piece of parchment paper on top of a large baking sheet so the cantaloupe doesn’t stick. Make sure there are no pieces on top of each other, and try to space them out as much as possible so each piece can caramelize in the oven. If you don’t have parchment paper, spray a piece of aluminum foil with canola oil or vegetable oil and place it on the baking sheet.

steps.headline: Roast the cantaloupe in the oven for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Position the baking sheet on the center rack of the oven and let the cantaloupe cook. After 20 minutes, check on the melons to make sure they’re shriveling slightly and becoming caramelized. If they aren’t ready, cook them for an additional 3 minutes. Remove the baking sheet from the oven once they’re a light brown color. If they’re a darker brown color or have shriveled up a lot, they are likely overcooked, but will still be okay to eat!

steps.headline: Let the fruit cool completely before serving.
steps.description:
Leave the cantaloupe on the baking sheet for at least 10 minutes so the melons cool down. Then carefully scoop the pieces off of the parchment paper and place them in a bowl to serve them. You can store the roasted cantaloupe in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to a week. After a week, discard the leftover cantaloupe and roast a new batch! Eating Roasted Cantaloupe
Top a bowl of yogurt or oatmeal with roasted cantaloupe for a healthy breakfast treat. Pair roasted cantaloupe with ice cream or custard if you want a sweet dessert. Garnish a scoop of sorbet with roasted cantaloupe for a healthy, fruity snack.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 320 °F (160 °C).
steps.description: Cantaloupe seeds can be more sensitive to high heat than other types of seeds, so cook them at a lower temperature. If you have an older analog oven that doesn’t have exact temperatures, set the oven to 300 °F (149 °C) and increase the cooking time to 30-40 minutes. As the oven is heating up, you can prepare your seeds for roasting. If you’re roasting seeds directly after roasting the melon, you'll need to give the oven time to drop in temperature before placing the seeds in the oven.

steps.headline: Rinse the seeds in a sieve and then pat them dry.
steps.description: To remove the seeds from the netting that holds them together in the melon, place them in a sieve and run them under room-temperature water to break apart the thick fibers, Use your hand to press the fibers through the sieve, and pick out the seeds. Then, place all of the seeds on a paper towel and pat them dry. It’s important that the seeds are mostly dry since the oil won’t stick to them if they’re wet, resulting in burnt seeds.

steps.headline: Coat the seeds in a mixture of 1 US tbsp (15 mL) of olive oil and some salt.
steps.description: Put the seeds in a medium mixing bowl with the oil and add a few pinches of salt to your personal taste. Mix them with a spoon or spatula until all of the seeds are coated in the oil and salt.Tip: If you prefer a much saltier taste, use 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of soy sauce instead of olive oil and salt!

steps.headline: Arrange the seeds on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper.
steps.description: Pour the seeds out onto a baking sheet that’s been covered with a sheet of parchment paper to prevent sticking. Use a spoon or spatula to evenly distribute the seeds across the sheet to ensure that they roast evenly. If the seeds are too close together or on top of each other, the seeds on the outside of the sheet might become burnt while the ones in the center aren’t cooked.

steps.headline: Roast the seeds in the oven for 22-23 minutes.
steps.description: Put the baking sheet on the center rack of the oven and keep a close eye on them while they cook. Once you can smell the seeds becoming toasty, take them out of the oven to taste one. If it’s crispy on the outside but slightly moist on the inside, the seeds are ready. Remember to increase the cooking time to 30 minutes if you’re using an analog oven set to 300 °F (149 °C). If the seeds aren’t done, lower the temperature to 300 °F (149 °C) and let them cook for an additional 4-5 minutes before trying another.

steps.headline: Store the seeds in an airtight container in the refrigerator or freezer.
steps.description: When they’re done, remove the seeds from the oven and let them cool for 10-15 minutes before placing them in a resealable container. Keep them in the refrigerator for up to 1 month, or store them in the freezer for up to 6 months. Never store seeds that have been cooked in oil at room temperature since the oil can become rancid.
